tasks.description: Receive and store the raw user query.
Preprocess the query: tokenization, lowercasing, stop‑word removal, and spell correction.
Perform intent classification to determine the user’s goal.
Extract entities and relevant attributes (e.g., location, date, product name).
Map the identified intent and entities to the appropriate domain(s) from the provided category list.
Select the most suitable external API(s) for each domain (e.g., weather API for weather queries).
Construct and send API requests, handling authentication and rate limits.
Collect and parse responses from one or multiple APIs.
Aggregate and reconcile data from multiple sources into a coherent information set.
Generate a natural‑language answer using templating or a language model.
Post‑process the answer: format dates, numbers, and URLs; apply personalization if needed.
Handle errors and fallbacks: provide graceful responses when APIs fail or data is missing.
Log query, intent, API usage, and response for analytics and continuous improvement.
Update or cache frequently accessed data to reduce API calls and improve latency.
Implement user authentication and profile management using OAuth 2.0, supporting social login via Instagram and email/password.
Integrate Google Maps API to display interactive maps, support zoom, pan, and custom markers for plant locations.
Develop photo capture and upload workflow, including Instagram API integration for posting and retrieving media.
Build plant identification module using image recognition (e.g., TensorFlow Lite) to suggest species from uploaded photos.
Create a plant database schema to store species information, medicinal uses, native status, and user-contributed notes.
Implement location tagging and geo-data storage, linking plant sightings to latitude/longitude and map markers.
Develop a social feed that aggregates plant posts, supports likes, comments, shares, and follows.
Set up community moderation tools: content reporting, user flagging, and admin review workflows.
Create a notification system for new posts, replies, and location-based alerts using push notifications and email.
Implement analytics dashboards to track user engagement, plant discovery rates, and map interaction metrics.
Design an API gateway with rate limiting, authentication, and logging to secure internal services.
Build responsive web and mobile frontends using React Native / Flutter, ensuring seamless map and media experiences.
Add offline data sync and caching so users can view and add plant sightings without continuous connectivity.
Provide data export options (PDF, CSV) for users to share plant lists and location data.
Ensure legal and privacy compliance: GDPR, COPPA, and data retention policies, including user consent management.
Search movies by title or keyword and return matching movie IDs and titles.
Search songs by title or keyword and return matching song IDs, titles, and associated movie IDs.
Retrieve the full soundtrack list for a given movie ID, including track order, titles, artists, durations.
Retrieve detailed information for a specific song ID, including artist, duration, release date, and related movie.
Provide filtering capabilities for search results by year, genre, artist, or movie.
Implement pagination for search and list endpoints to handle large result sets.
Offer autocomplete suggestions for movie and song titles based on partial input.
User authentication and profile management
Search and filter activities by location, date, type, and user preferences
Retrieve and aggregate reviews and ratings from multiple review platforms
Display daily deals and promotions for selected activities
Manage reservation booking workflow (select date/time, number of participants, special requests)
Process payments securely and handle transaction confirmation
Send reservation confirmation, itinerary, and reminders to the user
Provide detailed activity information and itinerary management
Handle cancellations, refunds, and rescheduling
Analytics and reporting for business partners (booking metrics, deal performance, review trends)
Geocode the user’s Australian address to obtain latitude and longitude.
Query the Sensis Yellow Pages API for pubs within a specified radius of the geocoded location.
Parse Sensis API responses to extract pub names, addresses, and unique identifiers.
For each pub, construct a Yelp API search query using the pub name and location.
Retrieve Yelp reviews for each pub, filtering to include only the most recent reviews (e.g., within the last 30 days).
Extract reviewer photos from the Yelp review data.
Merge Sensis pub data with corresponding Yelp review and photo data into a unified result set.
Design and implement a user interface to display the merged pub listings with reviewer photos.
Implement error handling for API failures, rate limits, and missing data scenarios.
Securely store and manage API keys for Sensis and Yelp, ensuring compliance with their usage policies.
Integrate with a telephony API to receive and route incoming calls to the assistant.
Implement blocklist management: CRUD operations for user‑defined blocked numbers.
Implement time‑based filtering logic to allow or deny calls based on user‑specified schedules.
Integrate with the user’s contact list to identify known contacts and apply special handling.
Add close‑friends identification feature, allowing users to tag contacts and prioritize them.
Develop harsh handling responses for blocklist violators (e.g., automated refusal, call termination).
Automate do‑not‑call requests to companies and political organizations on behalf of the user.
Implement logging and analytics to track call filtering decisions and user interactions.
Create a user interface for configuring blocklists, schedules, contact tags, and do‑not‑call preferences.
Ensure compliance with telecommunication regulations and privacy laws (e.g., GDPR, TCPA).
Incident Data Ingestion and Validation – Collect and validate incident reports from various sources.
Real‑time Response Time Tracking – Monitor and record response times from dispatch to arrival.
Injury and Casualty Data Capture – Store detailed injury and casualty information for each incident.
Demographic Data Integration – Enrich incident data with demographic attributes of casualties.
Pattern and Trend Analysis Engine – Analyze aggregated data to detect trends in response times, injuries, and demographics.
Hotspot Cluster Detection and Mapping – Use spatial analytics to identify clusters of incidents and high‑risk zones.
Visualization Dashboard for Incident Metrics – Provide interactive dashboards for real‑time monitoring and historical analysis.
Alert Generation for High‑Risk Areas – Trigger alerts when hotspot thresholds are exceeded or response times degrade.
Reporting and Export Functionality – Generate customizable reports and export data for external use.
User and Role Management – Manage access control for dispatchers, analysts, and administrators.
GIS Integration for Spatial Analysis – Integrate with GIS tools to support mapping and geospatial queries.
Data Security and Compliance – Ensure data privacy, encryption, and compliance with relevant regulations.
Implement user registration and authentication to manage alert recipients.
Create an API endpoint to trigger an emergency alert event.
Integrate with a telephony API (e.g., Twilio Voice) to place automated phone calls.
Integrate with an SMS gateway (e.g., Twilio SMS) to send text messages.
Integrate with the Facebook Graph API to send Messenger notifications.
Integrate with an email service provider (e.g., SendGrid, SES) to send alert emails.
Implement logging and auditing of all sent alerts for compliance and troubleshooting.
Develop mobile app push notification handling to inform users of incoming alerts.
Add scheduling and retry logic for failed delivery attempts across all channels.
Set up monitoring and alert failure reporting to notify administrators of delivery issues.
Retrieve emails from the user’s email provider via IMAP/POP3 or API.
Analyze and score email importance using keyword, sender, and metadata heuristics.
Send a phone call notification using a VoIP/Telephony API.
Send an SMS notification via an SMS gateway.
Send an instant message notification (e.g., Slack, Teams) via their respective APIs.
Send a Twitter Direct Message using the Twitter API.
Delegate the email to a specified user by forwarding or assigning it in the system.
Manage user preferences for notification channels and delegation rules.
Store notification logs and email metadata for audit and analytics.
Handle authentication, authorization, and secure storage of credentials.
Acquire the user's current geographic location (latitude and longitude) using device sensors or IP geolocation.
Construct and send an authenticated request to Google's secret Weather API with the obtained location parameters.
Receive and parse the API response, extracting relevant weather metrics (temperature, humidity, wind, forecast, etc.).
Format the extracted data into a natural language summary suitable for speech output.
Use a text-to-speech engine to vocalize the weather summary to the user.
Handle errors gracefully (e.g., network failures, API errors, location not available) and provide fallback messages.
Implement OAuth authentication for Twitter and LiveJournal to obtain user access tokens.
Retrieve the authenticated user’s friends/followers list and download each friend’s profile picture.
Normalize and preprocess images (resize, crop, color correction) to a uniform tile size suitable for mosaics.
Generate a mosaic grid algorithm that arranges the processed tiles into a cohesive image, optionally allowing user‑selected layout or theme.
Provide a preview interface where users can view and adjust the mosaic before finalizing.
Offer product selection (mug, T‑shirt, mousepad, bag) with size and material options, and calculate final image resolution requirements.
Integrate with a printing service API to submit the final image and product details for order fulfillment.
Manage order processing, payment handling, and shipping status tracking.
Store user profiles, mosaic designs, and order history securely in a database.
Implement error handling, rate‑limit management, and caching for API calls to improve performance and reliability.
Add analytics to track usage metrics, conversion rates, and popular product choices.
Ensure compliance with privacy policies and data protection regulations for user data and images.
Authenticate the user with Twitter using OAuth and obtain necessary permissions.
Retrieve the authenticated user’s profile and contact list (followers/following) from Twitter.
Create a new conference call session using a conferencing API (e.g., Twilio, Zoom, or Jitsi).
Generate a unique, shareable call link and embed it in a tweet or direct message.
Provide a one‑click UI to start the call and automatically invite selected Twitter contacts.
Manage call participants (add/remove, mute/unmute) during the session.
Store call metadata (participants, duration, timestamps) in a database for analytics or future reference.
Handle call termination and clean up resources (destroy session, revoke tokens if needed).
Optionally send Twitter notifications or DMs to participants when the call starts or ends.
Identify and integrate a tide data API that supports bulk requests for the US, Pacific, Caribbean, and New Zealand regions.
Identify and integrate an astronomical data API to fetch sunrise/sunset, moonrise/moonset, and moon phase for each location.
Identify and integrate a solunar/fishing times API or algorithm to compute best fishing windows for each location.
Identify and integrate a photo service (e.g., Google Places, Unsplash) to retrieve a representative image for each location.
Design a data model to store location metadata, tide, astronomical, solunar, and photo information.
Implement a caching layer (e.g., Redis) to store API responses and reduce external calls.
Build a backend service that aggregates data from the integrated APIs, applies caching, and exposes a RESTful endpoint for the frontend.
Develop a frontend using Google Maps JavaScript API to display markers for each location and show an info window with tide, sun/moon, fishing, and photo details.
Implement pagination or clustering on the map to efficiently handle 3,000+ markers.
Add authentication and rate‑limit handling for external API usage.
Deploy the backend and frontend on a scalable platform (e.g., AWS Elastic Beanstalk, GCP App Engine).
Monitor performance, log errors, and set up alerts for API failures or latency spikes.
Discover and inventory virtual machines, containers, and hypervisors across all data centers and cloud providers.
Automate provisioning of new virtual servers, including image selection, networking, storage, and security group configuration.
Orchestrate migration of workloads from on‑premises to public or private cloud environments with minimal downtime.
Implement real‑time monitoring of resource utilization, health checks, and alerting for all managed hosts.
Provide auto‑scaling policies that adjust compute resources based on predefined metrics or schedules.
Manage configuration and compliance of virtual servers using declarative templates and version control.
Integrate a role‑based access control system with single sign‑on and multi‑factor authentication.
Generate dashboards and reports for capacity planning, cost analysis, and operational metrics.
Expose RESTful APIs for third‑party integration and automation scripts.
Provide a responsive web UI that allows administrators to view, manage, and troubleshoot the virtual infrastructure.
Gather geographic coordinates (latitude/longitude) for each of the New 7 Wonders.
Search and obtain the YouTube video ID for each wonder using the YouTube Data API or pre‑selected videos.
Acquire and configure a Google Maps API key and embed the map into the application.
Create map markers for each wonder using the coordinates from T1.
Attach info windows or side panels to each marker that embed the YouTube video from T2.
Design a responsive UI that displays the map and video player side‑by‑side or in a modal.
Implement error handling for API failures (Google Maps, YouTube) and missing data.
Optimize performance by lazy‑loading videos and minimizing API calls.
Deploy the application to a hosting platform (e.g., Firebase Hosting, Netlify).
Retrieve and cache the latest OpenDOAR repository list via its public API or RSS feed.
Geocode each repository’s address or name using the Google Maps Geocoding API to obtain latitude/longitude.
Fetch repository growth data from the ROAR API or dataset, including historical counts.
Merge the OpenDOAR metadata, geocoded coordinates, and ROAR growth figures into a unified data model per repository.
Expose a RESTful endpoint that returns the merged repository data in JSON, optionally filtered by region, subject, or date range.
Provide a separate endpoint that returns aggregated growth statistics suitable for charting (e.g., yearly repository counts).
Implement caching and scheduled refreshes to keep data up‑to‑date while minimizing external API calls.
Offer optional authentication or rate‑limiting for heavy usage scenarios.
Supply documentation and example client code for consuming the API.
Monitor API health and log usage metrics for future scaling.
Query Indeed API for job listings with tennis‑related keywords and US location filter.
Filter and rank the retrieved listings to ensure they are tennis‑specific and select the top 50 results.
Geocode each job’s address using Google Maps Geocoding API to obtain latitude/longitude coordinates.
Aggregate the geocoded data and prepare marker payloads for map rendering.
Render the first 50 job markers on a Google Maps instance, including info windows with job details.
Implement error handling, API key management, and caching to optimize performance and reliability.
Authenticate with the YouTube Data API v3 using an API key or OAuth 2.0.
Map user-selected categories (music, games, anime) to YouTube category IDs.
Build a search query that includes optional age rating filters (e.g., G, PG, R).
Call the YouTube Data API search endpoint with the constructed query, category ID, and age filter.
Parse the API response to extract video metadata such as title, thumbnail, channel, and content rating.
Filter the retrieved videos client‑side to ensure the age rating matches the user’s preference.
Implement pagination or infinite scroll to handle large result sets.
Design a Japanese UI for search input, category selection, age filter, and results display.
Cache search results locally or in a CDN to reduce API calls and improve performance.
Handle API quota limits, rate‑limiting, and error responses gracefully.
Provide a fallback or alternative content suggestion if no results match the filters.
Securely store, rotate, and manage the YouTube API key or OAuth credentials.
Authenticate and establish a connection to the Jacktracker API.
Retrieve the show metadata for *24*, including title, synopsis, and cast information.
Fetch the full episode list with episode numbers, titles, air dates, and plot summaries.
Download or link episode images such as posters and key stills.
Persist all retrieved data in a structured database for quick access.
Authenticate and connect to the Wayfaring.com API for forum functionality.
Create a dedicated discussion board for each episode (waypoint) using Wayfaring.
Associate each discussion board with its corresponding episode record in the database.
Develop a front‑end interface to display episodes, images, plot details, and embed the discussion boards.
Implement user authentication, session handling, and access control for the platform.
Add caching mechanisms and handle API rate limits to ensure smooth operation.
Deploy the application to a hosting environment and set up monitoring and logging.
Obtain and configure Flickr API key for authentication.
Implement Flickr photo search endpoint to retrieve geotagged photos based on query parameters (tags, date range, bounding box).
Parse Flickr API response to extract photo metadata: id, title, latitude, longitude, and photo URLs.
Generate photo URLs using Flickr's URL format for desired image sizes.
Initialize Google Maps JavaScript API and create the base map container.
Plot markers on the Google Map for each photo location, using custom icons or thumbnails.
Create a nested map view (e.g., a smaller map inside an info window) to show a zoomed‑in view of each photo location.
Add interactivity: clicking a marker opens an info window with photo details and the nested map.
Implement pagination or infinite scroll to load additional photos as the user interacts with the map.
Implement error handling, loading indicators, and fallback UI for API failures.
Optimize performance: lazy‑load images, cluster markers when many photos are present, and cache API responses.
Provide UI controls for search input, filters, and map navigation.
Deploy the mashup as a static site or serverless function, ensuring API keys are securely stored.
